sen.e: Agata-matsuri Festival is held on June 5 and 6 every year in Uji City, Kyoto Prefecture.

sen.e: Agata-matsuri Festival is held at Agata-jinja Shrine located 100 meters away from the south gate of the Uji Byodoin Temple.

sen.j: 6月5日の深夜、明かりのない暗闇の中で、梵天（ぼんてん）渡御と呼ばれる儀式があり、町内の男集が、梵天と呼ばれる神輿を担ぐ。
sen.e: In the middle of the night on June 5, a ceremony called Bonten togyo (Brahma-Deva imperial procession) takes place in the dark, where men in the village carry mikoshi (portable shrine carried in festivals) called Bonten.

sen.e: While this mikoshi passes through, houses turn off the lights to welcome it; thus the festival is called "Kurayami no Kisai (Strange Festival of Darkness)."

sen.e: It was once held on May 15 based on the old lunar calendar and known as "Ginkai-matsuri Festival."

sen.j: 大木を長さ数尺に切り、こぐちに笠をかぶせ、これを棒持し、「ぎんかり」「御ぎんかり」といいはやした。
sen.e: A large tree was cut into a length of several shaku (unit of distance approximately equal to 30.3 cm) to have a shade on its cut end, being carried upright with chants "ginkari" and "oginkari."

sen.j: 家々が明かりを落としているあいだ、各地から集まりきた多くの男女は狭い旅舎、民家に雑然と混臥し、相知らぬ男女が相接触した。
sen.e: While the houses turned off the lights, many men and women from around the country slept bundled together in small inns and private houses, where unknown men and women contacted each other.

sen.j: 妊娠すれば、神から子種をさずけられたとした。
sen.e: If a woman got pregnant, it was said that she was blessed with a child by the deity.

sen.j: 一説に、この祭は道饗祭に起こり、道饗と道鏡とは音が相通じるから、上のような性的な行事に付会され、道鏡を祭神と考えるようになったのであろうという。
sen.e: Some say that the festival originated from Michiae-matsuri Festival (or Dokyosai (道饗祭)), and as Dokyo(道饗) and Dokyo(道鏡, deity) were pronounced the same way, Dokyo was associated with the above-described sexual event, thus being regarded as an enshrined deity.
